subSection.paragraph: Review

paragraph.docTitle:
Distribution of the anti-inflammatory and anti-depressant compounds: Incensole and incensole acetate in genus
Boswellia

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Natural and Medical Sciences Center, University of Nizwa, P. O. Box 33, Birkat Al Mauz, Nizwa 616, Oman

paragraph.emphasis: Martin-Luther-University Halle-Wittenberg, Organic Chemistry, Kurt-Mothes-Str. 2, D-06120 Halle (Saale) Germany

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Incensole
Incensole acetate Cembranes
Diterpenes
Frankincense Anti-inflammatory Anti-depression
A B S T R A C T

Incensole and its acetate have shown anti-inflammatory and anti-depression activities due to their ability to activate ion channels in the brain to alleviate anxiety or depression. The natural occurrence of these two structurally and medicinally fascinating 14-membered diterpenoids was reported mainly from the genus
Boswellia
. Incensole and incensole acetate were detected in and isolated from both essential oils and resins of frankincense. One total synthesis was reported for incensole. Both incensole and its acetate served as precursors for several synthetic transformations. Given the fact that no specific enzymes were isolated from
Boswellia
trees, the major sources for incensole and incensole acetate, the biosynthetic pathway of these two compounds was only speculated. Recent studies on incensole and incensole acetate including ours have revealed another secret of the ancient drug. Understanding their mode of action will open a door in modern neurobiology and provides new insights on the mysterious diseases of the nervous system. This review interpretatively discusses the natural existence of incensole and incensole acetate, the variation of their percentages in different
Boswellia species
and other sources, their synthetic modifications, their biosynthesis and their therapeutic potential.

The interesting structural diversity of terpenes in general and diterpenes in particular in the genus
Boswellia
promoted isolation of several interesting cembranes and cembranoids, among which are the two molecules of interest; incensole (1) and incensole acetate (2) ( Fig. 1 ). Incensole was first isolated by Corsano and Nicoletti (1967) and ten years later, its acetate was reported by Obermann (1977) . Apart from the structural diversity furnished by nature, chemists have contributed to this diversity by modification of incensole and its acetate by functionalising the olefinic bonds as well as the hydroxyl group at C-5.

footnote.paragraph: Received 7 October 2018 ; Received in revised form 5 January 2019 ; Accepted 13 January 2019

Boswellia species

subSection.paragraph: Frankincense has demonstrated superior anti-inflammatory activities supported by clinical trials for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, ulcerative colitis, bronchial asthma, multiple sclerosis and several others ( Al-Harrasi et al., 2018a ,b). The majority of the reported activity of frankincense was claimed due to its rich content of boswellic acids known for their anti-inflammatory activity. Yet, incensole and its acetates have demonstrated potent anti-inflammatory and anti-depression activities to contribute to the overall activity of frankincense.

paragraph.tableNote:
a
Boswellia madagascariensis
has recently been given its own genus,
Ambilobea ( Eslamieh, 2017 )
and will therefore not be referenced in this review as a
Boswellia species.
Boswellia sacra Flueck
and
Boswellia carteri Birdw
are no longer two species but one and will appear in this review as
B. sacra
(syn
B. carteri
).

subSection.paragraph:
The important studies by Moussaieff ( Moussaieff et al., 2007 ,
2008 a
, 2008 b, 2012 ; Moussaieff and Mechoulam, 2009 ) revealed that incensole and its acetate are nuclear factor-κB inhibitors which suggests their contribution in the overall known anti-inflammatory activity of frankincense. Interestingly, incensole acetate (2) showed potent neuroprotective activity following a brain trauma in mice. Incensole acetate (2) has proved to be a potent agonist of the transient receptor potential (TRP)V3 channel. The anti-depressive and anxiolytic effects of incensole acetate was elucidated in mice.

This short review doesn't deal with diterpenes and cembranes in general, it rather focuses on incensole and its acetate as two featured molecules of interest. A more detailed review on the structural diversity of cembranes on
Boswellia
will follow. Moreover, a detailed review on the chemistry and biological properties of cembrane diterpenes can be found elsewhere ( Yang et al., 2012 ).

heading.emphasis: 2.1. Genus Boswellia as a major source for incensole and its acetate

subSubSection.paragraph:
Resins obtained from a few species belonging to the genus
Boswellia
are considered the major source for incensole and its acetate. This genus possesses a huge structural diversity and it is the sole source for the medicinally important boswellic acids ( Al-Harrasi et al., 2018a ,b).

Taxonomy-wise, the genus
Boswellia
(named after a Scottish botanist named John Boswell) belongs to the Burseraceae family of approximately 700 species originating from 18 genera ( Langenheim, 2003 ; Watson, 1992 ). The genus
Boswellia
has 21 known species but according to Eslamieh there are only 19 different species, and the other appear to be synonyms of the original species ( Eslamieh, 2017 ). Their distribution stretches from the Ivory coast to the Horn of Africa, from Yemen to Iran , Pakistan and India ( Eslamieh, 2017 ). These species are summarized in Table 1 .

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2.
Boswellia
trees from Oman and Yemen.

subSubSection.paragraph:
In south Arabia there are eight species. It is worthwhile mentioning that the island of Socotra in Yemen hosts seven rare species of this important genus ( Table 1 ) whereas
Boswellia sacra
is the only species available in Oman . Fig. 2 depicts some pictures of the different
Boswellia
trees growing in Oman and Yemen .

Frankincense is obtained by careful incisions made in the trunk of the tree to allow the milky substance to ooze out which then gets hardened by its exposure to air ( Fig. 3 ) ( Al-Harrasi et al., 2018a ,b).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. Frankincense oozes out of
Boswellia sacra
tree in Dhofar, Oman. Pictures are from the authors' lab.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Boswellia
trees produce resins known as frankincense which varies significantly in its physical ( Fig. 4 ) and chemical properties. This variation is reflected on its commercial value and is also seen in different grades of the same species. The content of the secondary metabolites in these resins also varies significantly. While some species are known to have more monoterpenes, others are characterized by their abundance of diterpenes or triterpenes. In this genus,
Boswellia elongata
from Socotra in Yemen and
Boswellia papyrifera
growing in Ethiopia , Eritrea and Sudan are characterized with the high content of incensole (1) and incensole acetate (2).

Despite the relatively small number of species in genus
Boswellia
, taxonomic controversy was clearly observed in several literature reports. The debatable argument about the synonymy of
Boswellia sacra
(syn
B. carteri
) ( South Arabia ) and
Boswellia carteri
(Africa) was well pronounced and evidenced. While some reports regarded the two species as the same ( Culioli et al., 2003 ), others suggested they are two distinct species ( Al-Harrasi and Al-Saidi, 2008 ; Al-Harrasi et al., 2013 ; Hamm et al., 2005 ; Thulin and Warfa, 1987 ; Woolley et al., 2012 ). Based on the recent publications ( DeCarlo et al., 2018 ; Eslamieh, 2017 ; Niebler and Buettner, 2016 ; Paul et al., 2012) and the clear differences in morphology and chemical profile of both the oil and resins, we now consider
Boswellia carteri
and
Boswellia sacra
as the same species but differing in their habitat.
Boswellia carteri
is native to Africa and
Boswellia sacra
is native to South Arabia ( Oman and Yemen ).

The argument to consider
Boswellia microphylla
to be a variety of
Boswellia neglecta
, and
Boswellia popoviana
to be synonymous to
Boswellia nana
based on ambiguous analysis lacks supported evidences. We adopt here Eslamieh's opinion ( Eslamieh, 2017 ) by considering all the four species as independent, and they will be treated in this review as such.

Another confusion in chemistry literature was seen when
Boswellia papyrifera
was referred to as
Boswellia carteri
; this finding was unambiguously disproved by isolating chemotaxonomic markers (Paul, 2012).

Incensole (1) was first isolated by Corsano and Nicoletti (1967) in 1967 from plant material which was thought to be from
Boswellia carteri .
Recent studies suggested the species of
Boswellia
used by Corsano was in fact
Boswellia papyrifera
. Ten years later, Obermann (1977) reached a completely different conclusion with regard to the
Boswellia species
that Corsano and Nicoletti had used. Obermann and his team have studied two essential oils of
Boswellia
named as “Aden” and “ Eritrea ” during which he concluded that “Aden” type is mainly the fraction of neutral triterpenes published by Snatzke and Vértesy (1967) . Furthermore, the GC-MS analysis revealed that incensole (1) was detected in infinitesimal amounts in the “Aden” type . In contrast, 1 and its acetate (2) were found in larger amounts in the “ Eritrea ” type . Interestingly, the percentage of incensole (1) found in the sample was comparable to that published by Corsano and Nicoletti (1967) . Moreover, Obermann (1977) found commercial “Aden” type to be similar to the commercial grade of Somalian
Boswellia carteri
. Another supporting evidence proposed by Obermann was his observation that the odor of the commercial Somalian frankincense resembles to a great extent the “Aden” type whereas “ Eritrea ” type differed significantly. A similar conclusion was drawn by Paul (2012) in his chemotaxonomic investigation on resins of the different frankincense species. These observations have unambiguously concluded that the “Aden” type analyzed by Obermann was in fact a resin from
Boswellia carteri
or
Boswellia sacra
given the fact that they both belong to the same species but differ in their habitat. We - in this review - support the hypothesis proposed by Paul (2012) that the “Aden” type could have been transported from Somalia to the port of Aden in Yemen which lead to its trade name “ Aden ”. Furthermore, the resin used by Corsano and Nicoletti from which they have isolated incensole is the “ Eritrea ” type which appears to be
Boswellia papyrifera
. This conclusion is evidenced by several published reports ( Camarda et al., 2007 ; Hamm et al., 2003 ; Obermann, 1977 ). Alemika ( Alemika et al., 2004 ) isolated incensole from stem bark of
Boswellia dalzielii
collected in Nigeria .

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Other natural sources for incensole and its acetate

subSection.paragraph:
Incensole and incensole acetate belong a large and structurally varied group of cembrane-type diterpenoids found in terrestrial plants, insects and marine organisms. These two molecules were claimed to exist in other sources than
Boswellia
. These include essential oils of
Coriandum sativum ( Moawad et al., 2015 )
,
Oenanthe javanica ( Pattiram et al., 2011 )
,
Labisia pumila ( Pattiram et al., 2011 )
,
Citrus reticulata ( Hamdan et al., 2016 )
,
Helichrysum italicum ( Maksimovic et al., 2013 )
,
Salvia officinalis ( Maksimovic et al., 2013 )
,
Cistus creticus
(Skori
ć et al., 2012
),
Salvia oligophylla ( Salimpour et al., 2011 )
,
Trianthema portulacastrum ( Abd El-Gawad et al., 2016 )
,
Frangula alnus ( Roudbaraki and Nori-Shargh, 2016 )
and
Hyphaene thebaica ( Ayoub et al., 2011 )
. Since there is no conclusive evidence of their existence by isolation and structural elucidation, and the reports rely solely on their detection by GC-MS, these species as sources for incensole and its acetate remain uncertain.

heading.emphasis: 3. Quantification of incensole (1) and incensole acetate (2)

subSection.paragraph:
A thin layer chromatography method to identify incensole and incensole acetate in three olibanum samples was reported by Paul et al. (2012). This study has concluded that incensole (1) and incensole acetate (2) are markers for
Boswellia papyrifera
. Thereby, both compounds appeared as brown spots in the TLC when sprayed with anisaldehyde at
Rf
value of 0.27 and 0.68, respectively.

Recently we have employed NIR spectroscopy coupled with PLSR to quantify incensole in three
Boswellia species
( Al-Shidhani et al., 2018 ). The results concluded that a methanol extract of
Boswellia papyrifera
holds the highest amounts of incensole (18.4%) followed by a n -hexane fraction (13.5%) and an ethyl acetate fraction (3.6%) while only trace amounts were detected in the fractions of
Boswellia sacra
(syn
B. carteri
).
Boswellia serrata
proved complete absence of incensole. This method offered a robust, quick and nondestructive technique to quantify incensole.

There are many reports describing the analysis of essential oils from different
Boswellia species
mentioning incensole and its acetate. However, there is a clear controversy in most of these reports which could be attributed to the fact that the analyzed resins were purchased from local markets without proper taxonomic identification. Most of these reports described hydro-distillation as a method for production of essential oils from frankincense species.

Incensole and its acetate were reported from various
Boswellia species
( Table 2 ). Incensole (1) was reported from ten
Boswellia species
whereas its acetate was reported from five species both with varying concentrations and in a few cases with doubtful results. Recently, we have employed NIR spectroscopy coupled with PLSR and cross-validated by HPLC to quantify incensole and its acetate from
Boswellia sacra
of a certified botanic origin collected from Dhofar , Oman ( Al-Shidhani et al., 2018 ). Incensole was detected in 0.42% using NIR and 0.39% by HPLC. Using both methods,
Boswellia sacra
(syn
B. carteri
) showed the complete absence of incensole acetate.

There are several reports on the analysis of essential oils obtained from
Boswellia sacra
(syn
B. carteri
) using different methods of extraction/distillation and different methods of analysis; all of them reported the complete absence of incensole and its acetate ( Al-Harrasi and Al-Saidi, 2008 ; Hamm et al., 2005 ; Niebler et al., 2016; Paul, 2012).

subSubSection.paragraph:
the synonymous species of
Boswellia sacra
was the most analyzed species. Basar in her thesis ( Basar, 2005 ) reported 1.0% of incensole and 2.2% of its acetate from
Boswellia carteri
. However, as mentioned above, this species must have been confused with
Boswellia papyrifera
.

Surprisingly, Marongiu et al. (2006) reported relatively high content of incensole (6.1%) and its acetate (13.0%) from
Boswellia carteri
( Table 2 ) using hydro-distillation. In the same paper ( Marongiu et al., 2006 ), the authors found incensole (9.6%) and its acetate (26.2%) using supercritical carbon dioxide extraction from
Boswellia carteri
(90 bar, 45 ̊C). When varying temperature and pressure of the extraction method, a similar content of incensole (at 120 bar and 60 ̊C, 17.2%, at 120 bar, 45 ̊C, 17.8) and its acetate (at 120 bar and 60 ̊C, 30.9%, at 120 bar, 45 ̊C, 32.0) were observed. A comparable result (22.5%) was achieved by Ammar et al. (2013) , also from
Boswellia carteri
. A much less content (2.7%) of incensole was seen by Wahab ( Wahab et al., 1987 ). Given the fact that in all mentioned reports ( Ammar et al., 2013 ; Basar et al., 2001 ; Marongiu et al., 2006 ; Wahab et al., 1987 ),
Boswellia carteri
was referred to as “purchased from local markets” but not collected and taxonomically identified, the species were in fact
Boswellia papyrifera
and not
Boswellia carteri
. We wish this review clarifies this long-standing controversy between the two completely different
Boswellia species
(
Boswellia papyrifera
and
Boswellia carteri
).

In analogy to its synonymous species
Boswellia sacra
, other publications from
Boswellia carteri
reported a complete absence of incensole and its acetate ( Camarda et al., 2007 ; Hamm et al., 2005 ; Mikhaeil et al., 2003 ) using different methods for extraction, distillation and analysis.
is distributed in India and Sri Lanka ( Eslamieh, 2017 ) is one the least analyzed species ( Benelli et al., 2018 ) for which no incensole and its acetate were observed.

subSection.paragraph:
Neither incensole nor its acetate were detected in all published papers for the two African
Boswellia species
;
Boswellia rivae and Boswellia neglecta
except one result which claimed 39% of incensole acetate from
Boswellia neglecta ( Fanta et al., 2013 )
. This study has very likely used
Boswellia papyrifera
instead of
Boswellia neglecta
.

subSubSection.paragraph: is an important source of frankincense distributed in Ethiopia , Eritrea , and Sudan . It is the common frankincense tree in which incensole and its acetate are available in abundant amounts (Paul et al., 2012). Incensole and incensole acetate are biomarkers for this species in addition to n -otctanol and n -octyl acetate. All analyses reported for this frankincense confirmed the existence of both incensole and its acetate albeit the variation in their concentrations ( Al-Shidhani et al., 2018 ; Camarda et al., 2007 ; Hamm et al., 2005 ; Niebler and Buettner, 2016 ; Paul, 2012).

subSection.paragraph:
Analyses of
Boswellia pirottae
and
Boswellia frereana
revealed no presence of incensole and incensole acetate ( Basar, 2005 ; Ba ş er et al., 2003; Niebler and Buettner, 2016 ).

Socotra in Yemen hosts seven rare species of genus
Boswellia
. These include
Boswellia popoviana
,
Boswellia nana
,
Boswellia bullata
,
Boswellia dioscorides
,
Boswellia ameero
,
Boswellia elongata
,
Boswellia socotrana
. Among these seven species, only
Boswellia elongata
was found to have significant amounts of incensole and its acetate ( Mothana et al., 2011 ; Niebler et al., 2016). One single report revealed 1.7% of incensole in
Boswellia popoviana (Niebler et al., 2016)
. Other species either proved the absence of incensole or its acetate or their availability in tiny amounts ( Table 2 ) ( Ali et al., 2008 ; Mothana et al., 2011 ; Niebler et al., 2016).

caption.paragraph:
Table 2 Reported content of incensole (1) and incensole acetate (2) in various
Boswellia species
; ND, not detected; SCCO 2 , Supercritical carbon dioxide extraction; SPME, solid-phase micro-extraction; RI, retention index; GC-MS, Gas Chromatography - Mass Spectrometry; Supersacra, a hybrid variety created by cross-pollination of
Boswellia sacra
specimen with different clones of the same species (Niebler et al., 2016; Eslamieh, 2017 ); tr, trace; resin*, the resin was fumed to give pyrolysates prior to analysis.

subSection.paragraph:
Leaves of
Boswellia dalzielii
proved complete absence of both incensole and its acetate ( Kohoude et al., 2017 ). The essential oil obtained from the bark of
Boswellia elongata
revealed good amounts of incensole (14.8%) and incensole acetate (7.4%) ( Mothana et al., 2011 ).

Despite the scarce literature on the pyrolysates from frankincense, Basar in her thesis analyzed pyrolysates of
Boswellia serrata
,
Boswellia rivae
,
Boswellia negelecta
and confirmed the absence of incensole and its acetate ( Basar, 2005 ). As explained above, her report on the high percentages of incensole (22.8%) and its acetate (15.5%) from the pyrolysates of
Boswellia carteri
is due to the confusion between
Boswellia carteri
and
Boswellia papyrifera
. It can be concluded from the above analyses that incensole and incensole acetate are predominant in two
Boswellia species
only, namely
Boswellia papyrifera
and
Boswellia elongata
.

It is noteworthy mentioning that the method of extraction and to a lesser extent the quantification method has an influence on the final content of incensole and its acetate. This variation also holds correct with the same extraction method where distillation time, temperature and pressure can be critical factors. For example, quantification of incensole and incensole acetate in
Boswellia sacra
(syn
B. carteri
) (entries 1–3, Table 2 ) showed that using hydrodistillation, no incensole was detected whereas employing extraction, 0.42% was observed. Interestingly, when the same extraction method was used while utilizing NIR instead of HPLC as a quantification method, a small variation is seen in the concentration of the incensole. When discussing these variations, it is vitally important to refer to the same sample for all analysis, otherwise, the comparison will be meaningless as other factors may contribute to the overall concentration e.g. environmental conditions and time of harvest of the resin ( Al-Harrasi et al., 2018a ,b). Another example supporting the above argument is the difference in concentration of both incensole and incensole acetate using two methods of extraction and different parameters within the same method (entries 12–15, Table 2 ) as discussed above.

The biosynthesis of diterpenes starts from geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GGPP) ( A ). For the formation of incensole (1) and its acetate (2), Scheme 1 shows a possible biogenetic putative pathway. These two molecules are formed by loss of the pyrophosphate group from geranylgeranylpyrophosphate (GGPP) ( A ) to generate an active carbenium ion intermediate (B) which then undergoes a 1,14-cyclisation to generate the 14-membered carbenium ion scaffold (C). This may then either form cembrene A (D) via loss of a primary H + from the isopropyl group or cembrene C (E) via the loss of a tertiary H + from C-1 followed by an endocyclic conjugation (Paul, 2012; Breitmaier, 2006 ). Cembrene A (D) and cembrene C (F) are likely to be the biosynthetic precursors of iso-serratol (E) and serratol (G), respectively, via a biosynthetic hydrolysis of the precursors. Klein and Obermann (1978) reported serratol (G) as a biosynthetic precursor of incensole (1) and its acetate (2). An epoxidation of serratol (G) to afford epoxide (H) followed by an intramolecular cyclisation to form incensole (1) and then acetylation to incensole acetate (2) are likely the last steps of this reaction cascade ( Scheme 1 ).

As mentioned above,
Boswellia papyrifera
contains incensole (1) and its acetate (2) in high concentrations while other
Boswellia species
including
Boswellia carteri
,
Boswellia sacra
, and
Boswellia serrata
are reported to contain incensole (1) in only tiny amounts. Moreover, incensole acetate (2) was absent in
Boswellia carteri
,
Boswellia sacra
, and
Boswellia serrata
(Paul, 2012; Paul et al., 2012). Iso-serratol (E) and serratol (G) were observed in trace amounts in
Boswellia carteri
,
Boswellia sacra
, and
Boswellia serrata
. The reported biosynthetic pathway proposing iso-serratol (E) and serratol (G) as precursors of incensole (1) and its acetate (2) is implausible given the fact that no traces of 1 and 2 were detected in
Boswellia papyrifera
which contains high concentrations of compounds 1 and 2 (Paul, 2012). The high concentrations of incensole acetate (2) in
Boswellia papyrifera
could be attributed to the fact that this particular
Boswellia species
may follow a different route for expressing this molecule.
Table 2 ( continued )

caption.paragraph: Scheme 1. Biosynthetic pathway of incensole (1) and its acetate (2).

heading.emphasis: 5. Enhancement of incensole and incensole acetate in the resin of

subSection.paragraph:
The natural content of incensole and its acetate in the resin of
Boswellia papyrifera
is between 30 and 40% (Paul et al., 2012). A semipreparative partial-synthetic method for the enrichment of either incensole acetate or its acetate was developed by Paul and Jauch (2012) to practically enhance their content by converting into one another. Acetylation of the extract of
Boswellia papyrifera
was achieved by acetic anhydride in the presence of DMAP and pyridine followed by purification. This approach allowed the preparation of incensole and its acetate in gram-scale quantities. Hydrolysis of the crude extract was performed using KOH in i PrOH ( Scheme 2 ).

Pollastro et al. (2016) prepared various analogs to generate chemical diversity in the incensole skeleton, as shown in Scheme 3 . Incensole (1) was initially acylated to prepare compounds holding different alkyl side chains, such as 3 (nonanoyl ester), 4 (benzoyl ester), or the introduction of a phenylacetate or a cinnamate group to provide compounds 5 and 6, respectively.

Epoxide (7) was obtained treating 1 with m CPBA, which was then converted into acetate (8). On the other hand, epoxidation of incensole acetate (2) with m CPBA yielded a separable mixture of two regio-isomeric epoxides (8 and 9) each with 29% yield. The chemo-selectivity of the epoxidation of incensole (1) or its acetate (2) is not clear but might be attributed to the differences in the conformations of the two molecules due to complexation with the epoxidizing agent. Oxidation of the C-5 OH group with PCC provided incensone (10). Reduction of the C-5 ketone group of 10 with LiAlH 4 afforded a separable mixture of epi - incensole (11; 53%) and incensole (1; 28%) ( Pollastro et al., 2016 ). Moreover, reduction of ketone 10 with NaBH
4 in
EtOH provided a 50:50 mixture of compounds 1 and 11 ( Avula et al., 2016 ).

Following our continued interest in
Boswellia
research, we ( Rehman et al., 2017 ) have recently isolated a new incensole derivative named incensfuran from
Boswellia papyrifera
(12) ( Scheme 4 ). The structure of the isolated compound was confirmed via 1D and 2D NMR techniques and single crystal X-ray analysis. ECD and VCD spectroscopy was used to determine its absolute configuration. Incensole (1) is very likely a precursor for the biosynthesis of 12 via an intramolecular epoxidation between C-5 and C-8. This was supported by synthesizing compound 12 by treating 1 with BF 3 ·OEt 2 . Epoxidation of compound 12 afforded the corresponding epoxide analog 13 in 80% yield ( Rehman et al., 2017 ).

heading.emphasis: 7. Total synthesis: Kato's total synthesis of dl-incensole

subSection.paragraph: For the synthesis of dl-incensole (19) geranyl geranic acid chloride (14) was employed as a starting material by Kato et al. (1976) . Reaction of compound 14 with SnCl 4 at −78 ̊C afforded cyclized product 15 while treating of the later with tri- n -butyltin hydride followed by LiAlH 4 reduction afforded dl-mukulol (16). Reaction of 16 with TBCO (tetrabromocyclohexadienone) furnished the bromo analog 17 in 54% yield. Reaction of 17 with BF 3 ·Et 2 O at −15 ̊C gave compound 18. Furthermore, dl-incensole (19) was obtained by Ag-mediated solvolysis (AgOAc, HOAc) followed by LiAlH 4 reduction of the intermediate acetate ( Scheme 5 ).

caption.paragraph: Scheme 2. Jauch's focusing approach for large-scale preparation of incensole and its acetate.

heading.emphasis: 8.1. Anti-depressant activity of incensole and their derivatives

subSection.paragraph:
Numerous reports have described the anti-inflammatory properties of
Boswellia
. However, a majority of these reports have attributed the anti-inflammatory properties of
Boswellia
resin solely to boswellic acids and their natural and synthetic derivatives ( Al-Harrasi et al., 2018a ,b). However, recent reports ( Moussaieff et al., 2007 ,
2008 a
, 2008 b, 2012 ; Moussaieff and Mechoulam, 2009 ) proved the contribution of incensole and incensole acetate to the overall pharmacological action of the frankincense by inhibition of factor-κB activation.

Incensole acetate (2) induced calcium influx in TRPV3 channels ( Moussaieff et al., 2008a ). This important result was based on the activation of TRPV3 and TRPV 3 in primary mouse keratinocytes and then activation of TRPV3 current in HEK293 cells. It was found that the activity of incensole acetate (2) on TRPV3-induced calcium influx was comparable with the effect of 2-aminoethoxydiphenyl borate, a known TRPV3 activator.

caption.paragraph: Scheme 3. Analogs of incensole (1): Reagents and conditions: (i) appropriate acyl chlorides or anhydrides, py. (ii) m CPBA, EtOAc, rt (iii) acetylation (iv) pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC), CH 2 Cl 2 , rt, 5h (v) LiAlH 4 , THF, rt, 2h.
Scheme 4. Formation of compounds 12 and 13. Reagents and conditions: (i) BF3·OEt2 (1.5 eq), CH2Cl2, 0 ̊C to rt, 5 h; (ii) m CPBA, CH2Cl2.

subSection.paragraph: Further experiments ( Moussaieff et al., 2012 ) proved a significant submissive behavior and potent antidepressant-like activity following the administration of incensole acetate (2) in much lower doses ( 10 mg / kg). Moreover, introduction of 1 or 5 mg /kg/day of incensole acetate (2) for three weeks resulted in a decrease in submissiveness of mice which provided additional proof the potent antidepressant effects of incensole acetate (2). This group has also reported a significant decrease of corticosterone levels which further supported the antidepressant effects ( Moussaieff et al., 2012 ).

Prabhakar Adake et al. used experimental models of depression such as forced swim test (FST) and tail suspension test (TST) in Swiss albino mice, to evaluate the antidepressant activity of a crude extract of
Boswellia serrata ( Prabhakar Adake and Rao, 2013 )
. A significant reduction has been seen for the immobility period of 54 ± 20.26 s (p <0.001) compared to a control group (139.33 ± 11.04 s ), when
Boswellia serrata
( 100 mg /kg) was given with imipramine ( 10 mg /kg) followed by a forced swim test. Similarly, when compared to control group (245 ± 11.26 s ) with p <0.05, the immobility period was reduced to 160.33 ± 13.93 s by using tail suspension test.

Incensole acetate (2) displayed a significant potency with EC 50 = 1.4 ± 0.2 μM, and it has stimulated the TRPV3-mediated calcium influx. The incensole (1) and incensone (10) were synthesized by hydrolysis of the acetate and oxidation, respectively. Both incensole (1) and incensone (10) showed moderate potency with EC 50 values of 2.1 ± 0.2 and 2.4 ± 0.2 μM, respectively, while in case of incensole (1), the efficacy was higher. Compounds 11 (EC 50 = 7.3 ± 0.3 μM), 8 (EC 50 = 8.8 ± 0.5 μM) and 9 (EC 50 = 8.6 ± 0.4 μM) displayed lower potency than 10. A similar trend in the activity was observed for compound (6) obtained by replacement of the acetate with cinnamate. Compounds 3–5 ( Scheme 3 ) were achieved by replacing the acetate with nonanoate, benzoate and phenylacetate, respectively; these compounds also showed moderate potency ranging between 1.2 ± 0.2 and 5.6 ± 0.8 μM. Serratol (G) was the most potent TRPV3 activator. The affinity of incensole for TRPV3 was significantly improved by chemical modifications such as acylation, epimerization, and oxidation. Esterification of incensole (1) with lipophilic acids rendered it a potent NFκB inhibitor. Interestingly, incensole (1) but not incensole acetate (2) was a potent inhibitor of STAT3. This possibly suggests that a hydrolysis of 2 to incensole (1) is taking place in vivo .

heading.emphasis: 8.2. Anti-inflammatory activity of incensole and their derivatives

subSection.paragraph:
Boswellia
resins possess strong anti-inflammatory activities ( Gerhardt et al., 2001 ; Gupta et al., 1998 ; Ammon et al., 1993 ). Moussaieff et al. (2007) described a bioassay-guided fractionation of
Boswellia
resin and evaluated its anti-inflammatory effect using an inhibitor of the nuclear factor-kBα (I κBα) degradation in tumor necrosis factor (TNF) α- stimulated HeLa cells ( Moussaieff et al., 2007 ). Their study led to the isolation of two novel nuclear factor-κB (NF-κB) inhibitors from the resin, their structures were elucidated as incensole (1) and incensole acetate (2). Incensole acetate (2) inhibited the activation loop phosphorylation of TAK/TAB-mediated IκB kinase (IKK). This resulted in inhibiting cytokine and lipopolysaccharide-mediated NF-κB activation. However, incensole acetate (2) showed no effect on IKK activity in vitro , and no suppression of IκB phosphorylation in co-stimulated T-cells. This suggests that the kinase inhibition is neither direct nor does it affect all NF-κB activation pathways. Interestingly, incensole acetate 2 is specific and did not interfere with TNF-induced activation of c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) and p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase. ( Moussaieff et al., 2007 ).

caption.paragraph: Scheme 5. Synthesis of dl-incensole (19). Reagents and conditions: (i) SnCl 4 , CH 2 Cl 2 , -78 ̊C, 1.5 h; (ii) a: tri- n -butyltin hydride; b: LiAlH 4; (iii) TBCO, CH 2 C 12 ; (iv) BF 3 ·Et 2 O, −15 ̊C, 1 h; (v) AgOAc, HOAc, 55 ̊C, 2 h; (vi) LiAlH 4 .

subSection.paragraph:
Incensole acetate (2) also inhibited the production of inflammatory mediators in in vitro model of C6 glioma and human peripheral monocytes ( Moussaieff et al., 2008b ). The effect of incensole acetate (2) was examined on the inflammatory process and on the recovery of neurobehavioral and cognitive functions in a mouse model of closed head injury (CHI). In the brains of post-CHI mice ( Berrrrpohl et al., 2007 ; Lu et al., 2005 ; Shohami et al., 1996 , 1999 ), incensole acetate (2) reduced glial activation, inhibited the expression of interleukin-1β, and TNFα mRNAs, and induced cell death in macrophages at traumatized areas. Moreover, a mild hypothermic effect was also observed. Subsequently, incensole acetate (2) inhibited hippocampal neurodegeneration and exerted a beneficial effect on the functional outcome after CHI. This was observed by reduced neurological severity scores and improved cognitive ability in an object recognition test. This study attributed the anti-inflammatory activity of
Boswellia
resin to incensole acetate (2) and related cembranoids. ( Moussaieff et al., 2008b ).

Incensole acetate (2) displayed a remarkable neuroprotective activity in an in vivo model, but its in vitro anti-inflammatory activity was smaller (IC 50 value more than 100 μM against NF-κB activation) ( Moussaieff et al., 2007 ). In order to evaluate the anti-inflammatory activity of modified incensole, Pollastro et al. synthesized 12 different derivatives of incensole acetate (2) and developed a complete structure activity relationship for NF-κB (STAT3) inhibition ( Pollastro et al., 2016 ). Most of these derivatives with exception of 3 and 5 showed only weak activities with IC 50 values larger than 50, suggesting doubtful involvement of NF-κB in in vivo . Incensole (1), but not incensole acetate (2), proved potent on IL-6-induced STAT3 activation (IC 50 = 15.8 ± 2.88 μM) due to the involvement of STAT 3 in neuroinflammation. This suggests its involvements, secondary to enzymatic deacetylation, in the in vivo neuroprotective activity of incensole acetate (2).
Incensole (1) proved more potent than incensole acetate (2) in vivo , since the latter compound is rapidly deacetylated in vivo .

Incensole (1) and its acetate (2) are early cembrane-type diterpenoids with promising anti-inflammatory and antidepressant-like activity. These two structurally and therapeutically fascinating molecules revealed another secret of the ancient drug: frankincense. Their presence in the resin of some
Boswellia species
contribute to the overall pharmacological action of frankincense by inhibiting Factor-κB activation that was earlier believed to be solely due to the presence of boswellic acids in frankincense.

While incensole and its acetate have proved exceptional anti-inflammatory and antidepressant-like activity, more partial syntheses to evaluate the structure-activity-relationship profile of their synthetic analogs have to be solicited. Moreover, given the fact that the isolation and purification of incensole and its acetate from the natural resins is very tedious and since there was only one total synthesis reported, more facile total syntheses should be developed to allow more evaluations of the biological activities including the anti-cancer activities. It is worthwhile mentioning here the Jauch's efficient preparation of incensole or its acetate from the resin of
Boswellia papyrifera
tree employing acetylation or deacetylation followed by HPLC purification. This method allowed gram-scale quantities of both molecules but need access to either
Boswellia papyrifera
or
Boswellia elongata
.

Furthermore, naturally occurring incensole (1) and incensole acetate (2) are lipophylic in nature, which is a limiting factor in terms of their poor bioavailability. Thus, new methods to improve their delivery are to be developed including preparations of glycosides and nanoparticles. This may also include the synthesis of hybrid molecules of incensole with known soluble drugs.

There has been a long-standing controversy in literature with regard to the existence of incensole and its acetate in
Boswellia sacra
or its synonymous species
Boswellia carteri
. This review concluded - based on various analyses - that
Boswellia papyrifera
and
Boswellia elongata
are the two major sources of incensole and its acetate. Therefore, reports claiming the availability of both incensole and/or its acetate should be revisited and corrected. Moreover, reports of plants other than
Boswellia
claiming to contain incensole and its acetate based only on the analysis of their essential oils should be verified. Moreover, efforts to protect the frankincense trees containing incensole and its acetate from becoming extinct should be performed immediately.

The biosynthetic pathway to incensole and its acetate is speculated, and the isolation of precursors like serratol have validated its feasibility. However, isolation of enzymes from frankincense trees containing both incensole and its acetate should provide a strong evidence to support their biogenetic origin. Furthermore, genomic and transcriptomic studies of
Boswellia
trees will form a ground to answer many questions that chemical analysis could not answer.

Studies by Moussaieff and his team have provided a robust ground and paved the road to understand the anti-depression like activity of incensole acetate which helped coupling the ethno-pharmacology of the ancient drug with modern neurobiology. Future studies are expected to provide new insights on the mysterious diseases of the nervous system.

Incensole acetate and its natural analogs that have been used in many pharmacopeias for thousands of years being components of
Boswellia
resins. They are apparently safe as no side effects were reported, and they were very effective. Recent studies supported this fact reporting incensole acetate of very low toxicity, and no signs of toxicity in animals were observed even when they were treated with high and multiple doses of incensole acetate.

subSection.paragraph: Prof. Ahmed Al-Harrasi received his BSc in Chemistry from Sultan Qaboos University ( Oman ) in 1997. Then he moved to the Free University of Berlin from which he obtained his MSc in Chemistry in 2002 and then his PhD in Organic Chemistry in 2005 as a DAAD-fellow under the supervision of Prof. Hans-Ulrich Reissig. His PhD work was on New Transformations of Enantiopure 1,2-oxazines. Then he received the Fulbright award in 2008 for postdoctoral research in chemistry for which he joined Prof. Tadhg Begely group at Cornell University where he worked on Synthesis of isotopically-labeled thiamin pyrophosphate.

After a postdoctoral research stay at Cornell University in 2009, he started his independent research at the University of Nizwa, Oman where he founded the chair of Oman's Medicinal Plants and Marine Natural Products merging chemistry and biology research. He is currently a professor of organic chemistry and the Vice Chancellor for Graduate Studies, Research and External Relations at the University of Nizwa. He is the founder and chairperson of the Chair of Oman's Medicinal Plants and Marine Natural Products. The budget of his interdisciplinary-funded projects exceeds seven millions USD. He was a chair and invited speaker in many international conferences. He is a referee for more than 15 international chemistry and biotechnology Journals. He has authored and co-authored over 300 scientific papers, one book and 6 book chapters. He taught many chemistry courses both at MSc and BSc levels.

René Csuk , was born in Zurich / Switzerland and is Austrian citizen. He got his academic education at the University of Technology in Graz/ Austria , and received both his diploma (1981) and his PhD thesis (1984) under the supervision of Prof. Hans Weidmann “with distinction”. After having been appointed to a University Lecturer in 1984 for advanced NMR spectroscopic methods, he moved 1986 for a postgraduate study to Zurich (Prof. Andrea T. Vasella) working in the field of the total synthesis of natural products. He joined 1989 the group of Prof. Richard Neidlein at the Ruprecht-Karls University Heidelberg, and finished his “Habilitation” in 1992 (“Pharmaceutical Chemistry”) and was appointed Associate Professor(C3) in the same year (“Pharmaceutical Chemistry and Pharmaceutical Biochemistry”). He is since 1995 full professor of Organic Chemistry (C4) at the Martin- Luther-University Halle-Wittenberg. During 1996 until 2003 he served as a dean to his faculty, was appointed in 2001 as a director of the “Biocenter Halle”, 2015 as fellow of the Royal Chemical Society and in the same year as an editor of the “Europ. J. Med. Chem.” Prof. Csuk has authored more than 250 scientific papers, 12 books or book chapters and several patents. His main interests are natural products, stereoselective synthesis, chemoenzymatics and the synthesis of anti-tumor, anti-viral and anti-dementia active compounds, but he is also interested in historic and ancient dyes and colorants.

Ajmal Khan s/o Mr. Ahmad Gul was born on 3rd January 1983 in a small village Dargai, District Malakand, KPK, Pakistan . He passed his early education from Govt. Higher Secondary School Dargai No-1, District Malakand. Dr. Khan received his B.Sc degree from University of Malakand and M.Sc degree with distinction from University of Peshawar, Pakistan . In 2007 Dr. Khan got scholarship from HEJ Research Institute of Chemistry for Ph.D and completed his Ph.D. in field of enzymology at 2013. During his PhD, he received split PhD scholarship from OAED Austria , and worked as visiting scientist in University of Innsbruck, under the supervision of Prof. Dr. Bernd Michael Rode (Institute of General, Inorganic and Theoretical Chemistry University of Innsbruck, Austria ). Dr. Khan has expertise in enzyme inhibition, Enzyme kinetics studies, STD NMR studies for protein-ligand interaction. He has published more than 160 articles in international peer reviewed journals with impact factor of more than 350 and citation more than 1000. Beside this, he has four US patents, two of them published and the other two are filed up. He got five times Research Productivity Award from Pakistan Council of Science and Technology and twotime best poster award in international symposiums.

Javid Hussain was born in Kirman Kurram Agency, Pakistan . He received his B.Sc. degree from F.G. Degree College, Peshawar and M.Sc. from Gomal University, D.I. Khan. J. Hussain obtained his Ph.D. degree in 2005 under the supervision of Prof. Viqar Uddin Ahmad from International Center for Chemical and Biological Sciences, H.E.J. Research Institute of Chemistry, Karachi Pakistan in the field of Natural Product and Synthetic Organic Chemistry. Dr. Hussain worked as HEC postdoctoral fellow at University of Glasgow , UK on asymmetric synthesis. He started his career as Lecturer at Department of Chemistry, Kohat University of Science and Technology, Pakistan in 2004 and was promoted to Assistant Professor in the same Department in 2005. In September 2010 , he moved to University of Nizwa, as Associate Professor. Currently, he is Professor and Head of Department of Biological Sciences and Chemistry, University of Nizwa, Sultanate of Oman .
